urn:contentItem:58SV-XH81-F0JP-W2W8-00000-00Arizona disaster as 19 firies die in blaze2013-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Arizona disaster as 19 firies die in blaze

AT least 19 firefighters were killed yesterday while battling a fast-moving wildfire in Arizona, officials said, in the deadliest incident of its kind in the US in decades.

The firefighters died while racing to contain the Yarnell Hill fire north of Phoenix, in what Arizona Governor Jan Brewer called ``as dark a day as I can remember''.

The deadly blaze came amid baking temperatures and tinder-dry conditions across the US southwest, with records broken over the weekend in Arizona and California.

The fire follows an already deadly forest fire season across the region.

US President Barack Obama paid tribute to those who lost their lives, in a statement issued while travelling in South Africa which lamented ``this terrible tragedy''.

``They were heroes - highly-skilled professionals who, like so many across our country do every day, selflessly put themselves in harm's way to protect the lives and property of fellow citizens they would never meet,'' he said.

The Yarnell Hill fire, believed to have been sparked by lightning, broke out on Friday (local time).

According to local forestry officials, it has blazed through more than 800 ha, spreading rapidly through the dry, forested area amid strong winds.

More than 250 homes are feared to have been destroyed in Yarnell, which has been evacuated.

``It appears the firefighters had to deploy their fire shelters and were overcome by the blaze,'' said an update on the Northeastern Arizona Public Information website, referring to last-ditch protection equipment.

Hundreds of residents of Yarnell and Peeples Valley were being evacuated, officials said.

Prescott Fire Chief Dan Fraijo said he was ``devastated'' by the loss of lives.

``We just lost 19 of some of the finest people you will ever meet,'' he said. ``We take safety precautions but sometimes, unfortunately . . . it just doesn't work out.''

Figures from the National Fire Protection Association show the Arizona deaths are the worst firefighter fatalities in a bushfire since 29 died in Los Angeles in 1933.

The toll also marks the largest loss of firefighters on US soil since the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Centre in New York, when 340 firefighters were killed, according to NFPA statistics.

``This is as dark a day as I can remember,'' said Arizona Governor Jan Brewer, as tributes poured in for the fallen.

``I guess it was a flash fire and it just turned around and it overcame them all.''

urn:contentItem:458V-5NT0-0197-82JB-00000-00<published>1998-01-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:45:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SPORT; Pg. 82</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Martial arts help Kelly kick on in racing</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>RAY THOMAS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AS a former Tae Kwon Do champion, apprentice Kelly Dunn has both the physical strength and the discipline to become a successful jockey.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Dunn certainly needed all her strength to keep the erratic Forest Fire on a straight course in the Mackellar Handicap (1400m) and win her first race at Randwick yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But the discipline is something she needs every day, ensuring she is up before 4am to ride as many as 10 horses at trackwork at Warwick Farm and conquer the "mind games" to keep her weight under control.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>"It can be very hard at times because you crave for a 'Mac Attack' or chocolate, things like that," said Dunn.</p><p>"That's where the self-discipline I've learned from Tae Kwon Do really helps me.</p><p> "But I've ridden a winner at Randwick and that will make it easy for the next month."</p><p> Forest Fire (15/1) gave Dunn a torrid ride. He was trapped at least five wide throughout then drifted towards the outside fence in the straight yet still won comfortably from Sound (8/1) and favourite Bound By Silence (11/4).</p><p> The 21-year-old is something of a late starter in racing, only beginning her apprenticeship last September, but such has been her impact that yesterday's success was her seventh winner from just 56 rides.</p><p> Dunn was always keen on becoming a jockey but, wise to the potential hardships in racing, she continued with her education.</p><p> In order to pay her way through university Dunn rode trackwork each morning at Warwick Farm, forging indelible links with trainer Paul Cave.</p><p> At the same time, she continued her training in Tae Kwon Do and won the national under 55kg title in 1995.</p><p> On graduation she took up a position as a primary school teacher but after six months packed her bags and headed overseas for 12 months, working in the stables of famous Irish trainer Aidan O'Brien and then at a breaking-in centre in America.</p><p> She returned to Australia last year and linked up with leading Perth trainer Lou Luciani for three months before returning to Cave's Warwick Farm base to begin her apprenticeship.</p><p> Thoroughbred Racing Board stewards granted Dunn her licence to ride in September then only five days later she rode her first winner at her first race ride on Exploding Success at Kembla Grange.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5KGT-52R1-JD34-V30C-00000-00Young gun cashes in2016-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisSHORTLISTFilmPg. 6Young gun cashes inANDREW PURCELL

Miles Teller is kicking off his comeback year with an unusual comedy that exposes arms dealing, writes ANDREW PURCELL.

"Some of my best friends are in the military. I grew up in a small town. We had army recruiters there the whole time," says Miles Teller.

His new movie, War Dogs, is screening on army and navy bases the week before general release, and he's a little nervous about how it will be received.

"My homeboy's a Navy Seal. He's deploying tomorrow and he was like, 'Looking forward to that new film'," Teller says. His friend may be surprised to discover the film isn't about war at all.

The script is based on a Rolling Stone article about two stoner kids from Miami who somehow scored a $300 million contract to arm the Afghan military.

Teller plays David Packouz, a massage therapist trying to make a buck selling sheets to retirement homes, who is recruited into the infinitely more profitable arms business by his best friend from high school, Efraim Diveroli.

Jonah Hill's Diveroli is utterly amoral: a cocaine-sniffing, Porsche-driving, money-hungry sociopath with a gift for telling people what they want to hear. Before he can legally drink a beer, he has mastered fbo.gov - the website where contracts with the US military are offered for tender.

By undercutting the competition, Packouz and Diveroli won a contract for more than 100 million rounds of AK-47 ammunition and millions of rocket-propelled grenades that they were drastically unprepared to fulfil.

As one might expect from director Todd Phillips, most famous for the Hangover franchise, War Dogs plays this absurd situation for laughs, but Teller insists the film never forgets what the guns will be used for.

"When you're talking about arms dealing during a war, there's a certain seriousness, a certain gravity that will come with that material," he says.

The closest Teller has come to being in the military was in his breakthrough film Whiplash, in which he played a young drummer under the tutelage of J.K. Simmons' fanatical instructor, a more punishing sergeant-major than any in the Marines.

Teller played drums in his church choir and a teenage band, the Mutes, but he practised for the role until his fingers bled.

Whiplash won the Grand Jury prize and the audience award at the Sundance Film Festival in 2014. "I want to be talked about the way people talk about Hoffman and De Niro and Pacino," he told Rolling Stone.

Naturally, he was soon offered a superhero franchise: Fantastic Four. Predictably, it stalled his career after it failed at the box office.

War Dogs is part one of a four-film comeback year. In Bleed for This, he plays boxing world champion Vinny Pazienza, who returned to the ring after a near-fatal car crash. As a young actor, Teller was sometimes told the scars on his face, the result of a road crash, disqualified him from roles, but for this they make sense.

He is now filming Granite Mountain, about a crew of Arizona firefighters overwhelmed by a rapidly spreading forest fire. Finally, in Thank You for Your Service, Teller plays a US soldier with post-traumatic stress disorder.

War Dogs is about the price of war, and the vast fortunes to be made far from the battlefield: Thank You for Your Service is about the cost, particularly the emotional toll on the families of servicemen.

Teller knows that his friend in the Navy Seals will be entertained by War Dogs (and that he's likely to share its cynical view of profiteering. Playing a wounded warrior was an altogether more daunting challenge. "I was so nervous about that. I didn't want to act like I'd been to war. That's such a sacred experience," Teller says. "I'm sure he'll have some more opinions when I'm playing a soldier."

War Dogs

Genre Comedy

Buzz Early reviews are positive, with praise for its "unique twist on war movies"

Director Todd Phillips

Stars Miles Teller, Jonah Hill,

Bradley Cooper, Ana de Armas Released Out now, rated M

TWO PHOTOS: Miles Teller (left) in War Dogs and with Jonah Hill (above).

How two dopers from Miami manage to win a huge military contract, writes ANDREW PURCELL.

"Some of my best friends are in the military. I grew up in a small town. We had army recruiters there the whole time," says Miles Teller.

His new movie, War Dogs, is screening on army and navy bases the week before general release, and he's a little nervous about how it will be received.

The script is based on a Rolling Stone article about two stoner kids from Miami who somehow scored a $300 million contract to arm the Afghan military.

Teller plays David Packouz, a massage therapist trying to make a buck selling sheets to retirement homes who is recruited into the infinitely more profitable arms business by his best friend from high school, Efraim Diveroli.

Jonah Hill's Diveroli is flamboyant and utterly amoral: a cocaine-sniffing, Porsche-driving, money-hungry sociopath with a gift for telling people what they want to hear. Before he can legally drink a beer, he has mastered fbo.gov - the website where contracts with the US military are offered for tender.

"Me and my friends did some hustles to try and make some extra money but it was never on that kind of scale," says Teller.

By undercutting the competition, Packouz and Diveroli won a contract for more than 100 million rounds of AK-47 ammunition and millions of rocket-propelled grenades that they were drastically unprepared to fulfil.

As one might expect from director Todd Phillips, most famous for the Hangover franchise, War Dogs plays this absurd situation for laughs, but Teller insists the film never forgets what the guns will be used for.

"When you're talking about arms dealing during a war, there's a certain seriousness, a certain gravity that will come with that material," he says.

The closest Teller has come to being in the military was in his breakthrough film Whiplash, in which he played a young drummer under the tutelage of J.K. Simmons' fanatical instructor, a more punishing Sergeant Major than any in the Marines.

Teller played drums in his church choir and a teenage band, the Mutes, but he practised for the role until his fingers bled.

Whiplash won the Grand Jury prize and the audience award at the Sundance Film Festival in 2014. "I want to be talked about the way people talk about Hoffman and De Niro and Pacino," he told Rolling Stone.

Naturally, he was soon offered a superhero franchise: Fantastic Four. Predictably, it stalled his career. Teller played the team's leader Mister Fantastic, but couldn't save the movie from lacklustre box office and scathing reviews.

War Dogs is part one of a four film comeback year. In Bleed for This, he plays boxing world champion Vinny Pazienza, who returned to the ring after a near-fatal car crash. As a young actor, he was sometimes told that the scars on his face, sustained in a serious road accident, disqualified him from the role, but for this part they make sense. It also can't hurt that he resembles a young Stallone.

He is now filming Granite Mountain, about a crew of Arizona firefighters overwhelmed by a rapidly spreading forest fire. Finally, in Thank You for Your Service, Teller plays an American soldier returning home with post-traumatic stress disorder.

Teller knows that his friend in the Navy Seals will be entertained by War Dogs. Playing a wounded warrior was an altogether more daunting challenge.

"I was so nervous about that. I didn't want to act like I'd been to war."

War Dogs is is out now.

urn:contentItem:5234-F791-F0JP-W2RH-00000-00Be `proactive', CFA told By-laws reliance `a bit naive' expert2011-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Be `proactive', CFA told By-laws reliance `a bit naive' expertBushfires | Adrian Bernecich

By-laws reliance `a bit naive' expert

THE Country Fire Authority is under fire for deciding to delay and possibly cancel Knox's bushfire danger period this summer.

The CFA last week said the restriction period, originally scheduled for mid-January, had been postponed in Knox and surrounding municipalities because of the recent cool and wet weather.

But University of Melbourne senior fire ecology and management lecturer Dr Kevin Tolhurst criticised the decision, saying Knox should join the other 55 (of 70) CFA-controlled councils now under restrictions.

``There is no reason why we can't have a forest fire at the moment and putting total faith in council by-laws seems a bit naive,'' Dr Tolhurst said.

``It's better to be proactive than reactive, because we can't afford to be blindsided by the rain.''

Under Knox Council by-laws, residents cannot light a fire in an open area without a permit, unless for a barbecue or heating.

But CFA region 13 operations manager Graeme Armstrong last week told the Leader that, unlike areas such as Nillumbik and Murrindindi, Knox had greener vegetation and wet conditions,

posing less of a bushfire threat.

He said if these conditions continued, the fire danger period might not be needed this summer, suggesting new and stronger council by-laws were sufficient.

``There is a lot of moisture in the ground and typically the eastern side of Melbourne has greener conditions,'' Mr Armstrong said.

``If this continues in Knox there might be no real need for it.''

Knox Mayor Sue McMillan said the CFA was best equipped to make the bushfire decisions but urged all residents be aware of risks all year around, not just during summer.

Do you think Knox needs a fire restriction period? Tell us at knoxleader.com.au

urn:contentItem:56SH-TYN1-JD3N-52HP-00000-00Name change for court2012-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 23Name change for court

THE Federal Magistrates' Court is set to get a fancier title under legislation that has passed Parliament's Lower House.

Under the legislation, the court will be renamed the Federal Circuit Court of Australia, recognising the service it provides to regional communities through its program of circuits. Last financial year, the circuit reached 33 rural and regional centres.

Its magistrates will also be called judges, with Attorney-General Nicola Roxon noting they should be granted a title that acknowledges their ``increasingly complex and difficult work''.

Doyle solar pledge

INNER-city residents and businesses will have access to cheaper solar panels under an election policy by Lord Mayor Robert Doyle.

Cr Doyle said he would introduce a solar panel bulk-buying scheme for the City of Melbourne to help reduce energy costs. He said that in the past five years electricity prices had risen by a third.

Fire chief appointed

ALAN Goodwin is Victoria's new chief fire officer.

Mr Goodwin, who has more than 20 years experience in the forest fire industry, replaces Ewan Waller, who did not seek reappointment.

Mr Waller was criticised by the bushfires royal commission and was the last remaining fire chief from the 2009 Black Saturday tragedy.

More control of biological agents

THE Federal Government will have more power to control biological agents that can be used as weapons under legislation that has passed the Lower House.

The legislative amendment gives the Government more discretion to impose or lift handling requirements on bodies that use agents such as anthrax and the foot-and-mouth disease virus.

Drugs women on death row

TWO foreigners are on death row after being found guilty of trafficking drugs in Malaysia as an Aussie woman awaits her fate.

Filipina Marivelle Gonzales, 31, was found guilty in the High Court for trafficking a kilo of drugs, mostly heroin. Indonesian woman Ani Anggraeni has also been convicted in a separate case of trafficking almost 4kg of methamphetamine.

Australian woman Emma Louise L'Aiguille, 34, (pictured) faces death by hanging if she is found guilty of trafficking 1kg of methamphetamine.

Her legal team says she is innocent and simply caught ``in the wrong place in the wrong time''.

The Herald Sun revealed that Ms L'Aiguille's boyfriend was the target of a police operation for several months. But he ran when police pounced on their car.

urn:contentItem:5CG9-0VP1-F0JP-W2C2-00000-00SUNDAY, JANUARY 122014-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisPg. 5SUNDAY, JANUARY 12

10.30am: The Bureau of Meteorology weather station in Bickley registers hourly weather observations The Forest Fire Danger Index (FFDI) peaks at 53 (Severe) in Bickley. Given hotter conditions in Parkerville, the index there peaks at between 50 and 60.

10.42am: The Grassland Fire Danger Index (GFDI), averaged over one hour, peaks at 30 in Bickley. It rises to 30-40 in Parkerville.

10.58am: The Parkerville-Stoneville fire starts after a power pole on a Granite Road property falls, igniting grass.

11.06am: Mundaring appliances mobilised. By the time the first firefighting crews arrive from Parkerville and Kiara, which were in Darlington at the time of the incident, the fire has spread and is running and spotting to a bridle path next to the creek line on Riley Road. Due to high fuel loads along the creek line, the fires intensity increases dramatically.

11.11am: DFES mobilises two aircraft and two Helitacs to the fire.

11.16am: The DFES Communication Centre pages additional resources and these crews begin to arrive.

11.20am: In the first 60 to 90 minutes, a combination of high fuel loads and the heat make the blaze difficult to control, even though significant ground and aerial resources are deployed.

11.42am Police requested to close Riley Road between Kintore and Lacy roads in Parkerville.

11.56am: Emergency Alert message issued to 8186 mobile SMS services and 1113 fixed line voice messaging services.

12pm: Air support is boosted by the addition of an Air-Crane helicopter. The deployment of aircraft is enhanced, with all available aircraft at the site. The 16 aircraft involved in aerial fire suppression operations make it the most dangerous undertaken in WAs history. Equipment deployed includes an aerial intelligence helicopter, three air attack supervisor helicopters, one air attack supervisor fixed-wing aircraft, six Helitacs, one Air-Crane and four fixed-wing air tankers.

12.59pm: Ambulance staff say that a person has fallen through the roof of a Stoneville house. Later pronounced dead in hospital.

1.15pm: Property losses first reported to the Incident Controller in Stoneville Road.

1.38pm: Property losses on Riley Road confirmed. Following concerted efforts by aircraft, the head of the fire is slowed but, with a change in wind direction to the south-west and an increase in the slope topography, the fires intensity increases again.

1.15pm-3.15pm: Considerable property losses occur as the fire travels into Stoneville. Ground crews employ both offensive and defensive firefighting strategies in an effort to minimise losses. The fire line intensities calculated indicated the head fire cannot be directly attacked until after 8pm. The forecast rate of spread is about 400m per hour. Under these conditions, only very well prepared and actively defended houses can be saved.

5pm: Community meeting convened at Mundaring Recreation Centre.

5.30pm: Situation report identifies 37 properties destroyed.

8pm: As weather conditions became more favourable in the early evening and, with the use of ground crews, aerial suppression aircraft and earth moving machinery, the fire is contained.

urn:contentItem:5PN1-M5Y1-JBJ7-N552-00000-00How 'unprecedented' early season heat baked Australia2017-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisHow 'unprecedented' early season heat baked AustraliaPeter Hannam

Last month's early-season bursts of heat sent temperatures of some parts of eastern Australia a full 16 degrees above average, new analysis by the Bureau of Meteorology shows.

Last month's early-season bursts of heat sent temperatures of some parts of eastern Australia a full 16 degrees above average, new analysis by the Bureau of Meteorology shows.

In a Special Climate Statement examining two pulses of extreme warmth that seared large areas of inland Australia from Victoria to Queensland, the bureau identified the many national and statewide September records that tumbled.

During the first of those events, which affected NSW on September 23-24, all but three inland sites set record hot days for September.

On September 23 alone, 62 per cent of NSW had its hottest September day on record. A second heat burst set records in some northern parts of the state that had only been set a few days earlier.

"Hot, dry northerly winds ahead of [a] trough and cold front contributed to New South Wales, southern Queensland, and areas in neighbouring States experiencing unprecedented hot weather for this time of the year," the bureau said in its report.

While associated with large high pressure systems, the bureau noted global warming had pushed up background temperatures by about a degree over the past century for Australia and the planet as a whole, making the occurrence of such extreme events more likely.

"Studies undertaken by the Bureau and other scientific institutions have shown that climate change has contributed to the severity and frequency of recent heat events, including spring warmth," it said.

The special report comes a day after new research showed Australian cities such as Melbourne and Sydney need to prepare for summer days when the temperature climbs to 50 degrees in decades to come - even if nations kept to Paris climate pledges to keep global warming to less than 2 degrees.

Big dry impact

The bureau's report also noted that unusually dry conditions contributed to the recent abnormal heat.

Both Sydney and NSW, for instance, posted their driest Septembers on record last month. Statewide, rainfall was just one-seventh of the usual amount for the month, extending a worsening dry spell that has lasted about three months.

Sydney, meanwhile, is on track to break the record for the most days in a row with less than 2 millimetres of rain.

The current record, spanning August-October 1989, stands at 64 days, a record likely to be match on Saturday and broken on Sunday, if current forecasts are correct, Blair Trewin, the bureau's senior climatologist, said.

Hot times

The recent significant heat emerged on September 21, with almost all the country recording above-average temperatures, the bureau said.

Australia as a whole recorded its warmest September day on record the following day, with a mean maximum temperature on 33.47 degrees. That was more than 6 degrees warmer than the September average, and eclipsed the previous September record of 33.39 degrees set on September 30, 1998.

For NSW, though, the biggest heat spike came on September 23, with a large inland area reaching 16 degrees above average during the day. (See chart below.)

Apart from setting NSW's first September day with a maximum of 40 degrees, the statewide average maximum of 35.81 degrees smashed the previous record set in 2003 by 1.61 degrees.

An odd quirk in the heat was the range during the day, with some areas warming 30 degrees from their overnight minimums.

Canberra Airport, for instance, ranged from 1.3-30.2 degrees during the day day, exceeding the previous record for any month of the year for the diurnal range.

Victoria posted its hottest September reading on September 23, with Mildura clocking a 37.7 reading.

For Queensland, the peak of the heat hit on September 27 when 36 per cent of the state had its hottest September day.

The state's mean maximum temperature that day reached was 37.79 degrees, eclipsing the previous September record of 37.43 degrees set in 1988.

Drought widens

The ongoing lack of rain in many regions has meant less cloud cover and available soil moisture to be evaporated, helping to drive daytime temperatures higher.

The bureau's latest drought statement, out on Wednesday, showed rainfall deficiencies are intensifying in inland regions, particularly in NSW. (See bureau chart below.)

There is some hope for better rainfall in the weeks ahead, including signs that the Pacific is tilting towards La Nina conditions.

During La Nina events, eastern Australia tends to have above-average rainfall although cyclones also tend to increase in frequency in the Australian region.

Before the change, though, farmers and fire fighters are in for an anxious few weeks if not longer.

As the bureau's special report noted, dangerous fire conditions emerged during the recent heatwaves, including during the shorter second wave at the end of September.

According to the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, values exceeded extreme levels at many sites across the country from September 22-27, the bureau said.

As the map below shows, most of the nation had fire danger index ratings very much above average at the end of September.

urn:contentItem:7X0P-VRX1-2RG7-353M-00000-00Crews brace for 'catastrophic' fire2009-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisCrews brace for 'catastrophic' fire

Riverina residents are being urged to prepare their homes for a hot, dry summer with the Rural Fire Service (RFS) warning catastrophic fire days can be expected.

The bushfire danger period is now in force across the entire region and it comes with changes to fire warning advice and a new fire danger rating system.

Community safety officer for the Riverina Highlands RFS zone, Peter Jones, says the new severe, extreme and catastrophic warnings clearly communicate the type of danger.

He says there is likely to be advance notice of a catastrophic rating.

"We can make those warnings that potentially in three to four days we will [have] a catastrophic day, and that's when we really start to get the message out that the weather conditions will be horrible," he said.

"So start preparing your properties, make sure you've got all that sort of stuff ready in case a fire does start."

On request the fire brigade can inspect properties to ensure they are adequately prepared.

Mr Jones says after good rain, the grass dries out quickly in the heat.

He says there is no forest fire ban yet, but he is urging people camping in the hills to take care when lighting fires.

Mr Jones says he hopes to avoid pine plantation fires like the destructive 2006 Billo Road fire, but there have already been a few minor fires in the past week.

"We expect a lot more wind factor and a lot more high temperatures and low humidity days," he said.

"The weather bureau is predicting a lot more of those days when temperatures are well into the 40s and as a result of a passing front we really think that wind speeds up to 100 kilometres per hour are really possible this year."

urn:contentItem:51M6-1N61-JD3N-53YG-00000-00Prison guards die in inferno2010-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 17Prison guards die in inferno

MEGADIM, Israel: Dozens of Israeli guards, trying to rescue prisoners threatened by the worst forest fire in the country's history, died when their bus became trapped in the inferno.

The fire tore through a forest near Haifa in northern Israel on Thursday, prompting urgent calls for international help to tackle the blaze as it continued to burn out of control into the night.

The Magen David Adom ambulance service confirmed it had recovered the bodies of 40 people who died in the inferno.

``Most of the dead were on board the bus,'' spokesman Zachi Heller said, referring to the coach carrying the prison guards.

As the guards raced toward the prison holding mostly Palestinians, a tree fell across the road, blocking their path.

With no way out, many of them were burned alive inside the vehicle. Others perished while trying to flee the flames.

Rescue workers still were searching for an unspecified number of people, among them at least two police officers listed as missing, presumed dead.

Visiting the scene, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the tragedy as an ``unprecedented disaster''.

The flames forced 12,000 people from their homes, levelled a village and threatened to cause irreparable harm to one of Israel's few forested areas.

Twelve hours after the fire broke out, it still was raging out of control, with fire officials saying the inferno had incinerated at least 800ha of land.

Israel issued a rare call for international assistance a measure of the severity of the disaster.

Turkey put aside recent tensions to pledge aid, and Mr Netanyahu's office said Greece, Spain and Cyprus agreed to send firefighting helicopters. Additional aid was coming from Britain, Russia, Egypt, Azerbaijan, Romania, Jordan and Bulgaria.

In Washington, President Barack Obama expressed his ``deepest condolences'' and said the US was looking into what kinds of aid it could provide.

urn:contentItem:4P8J-4070-TX52-F44J-00000-00Heatwave kills 500 people in Hungary2007-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 10

AFP

Heatwave kills 500 people in Hungary

BUDAPEST: The heatwave in central and southern Europe killed up to 500 people in Hungary last week, the chief medical officer has said.

Ferenc Falus said yesterday that from July 15 to last Sunday the heat in central Hungary ''contributed to the early death of 230 people, which nationally means about 500 deaths''.

While Britain experienced its worst flooding in living memory, southeast Europe was reeling from weather blamed for forest fires and economic hardship.

Hundreds of blazes have been reported in Greece, where two pilots died on Monday after their water-bombing plane crashed while fighting a fire. A similar aircraft crashed the same day at a fire in Italy, killing three people.

In Macedonia, thousands of firefighters, soldiers and locals battled to stop a forest fire reaching the country's second-largest city, Bitola.

In the Balkans, people were warned to stay indoors, with deaths reported in Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, and Romania.

Temperatures in the region topped 40C with Greece expecting a high of 45C today and Italy just behind at 44C.

Bulgaria experienced its hottest temperatures since records began, with the mercury shooting above 45C in parts of the country, and more than 860 people reportedly fainted in the streets in Romania.

In Serbia, the agriculture ministry said 30per cent of the country's annual harvest had been destroyed because of the heat, with wheat, soya and vegetable crops worst hit.

urn:contentItem:51MR-MSY1-JD3N-512Y-00000-00Inferno kills dozens2010-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Inferno kills dozens

RESPONDING to an unprecedented Israeli distress call, aircraft from Turkey, Greece, Cyprus and Britain dumped sea water and flame retardant on a woodland inferno that has killed dozens, displaced thousands and ravaged one of the country's most prized forests.

As the country mourned the dead, Israelis long known for their high-tech society and vaunted rescue missions abroad were stunned on Friday at their firefighters' helplessness in quelling the blaze, the worst forest fire in the nation's history.

Still, for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu embattled over the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace effort it was also a chance to show that Israel was perhaps not so isolated after all. Even the Palestinian Authority pitched in with firefighting units.

Suspicions of arson persisted on the second day of the blaze as it rampaged through the Carmel Forest near Haifa, Israel's third-largest city. Police said small brush fires that broke out on Friday appeared to have been deliberately set, though police chief David Cohen said it was possible the main fire erupted because of carelessness.

Anguished families began burying the 41 dead, most of them prison guards who perished on Thursday when the blaze engulfed a bus that was transporting them to evacuate a prison. Fewer than half had been identified by late Friday because bodies had been burned beyond recognition.

The human tragedy was compounded by the loss of precious woodland in a country where only seven per cent of the land is forested. Tree-planting has an almost mystical quality here: for decades, Jews the world over have dropped coins into blue-and-white boxes of the Jewish National Fund, which has planted 240 million trees in the Carmel Forest and elsewhere across Israel since its founding in 1901. Though the scorched woodland covered an area of only about 21sq km or about one per cent of Israel's forest land the fire was felt as a deep national loss.

Outside Haifa, wind-driven flames towered nearly 30m.

urn:contentItem:4SJG-33G0-TX5N-00W6-00000-00Hot lessons for young Spaniard2008-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisPg. 16Hot lessons for young Spaniard

YOUNG Spanish forester Javier Martin Morena Meijias came to WA a year ago fired up to improve his English and enjoy the good weather, but he has ended up fighting fires as well.

He trained as a forest engineer in Spain and joined the Department of Environment and Conservation on arrival in Perth to learn more about forest and wildfire control.

His experience has turned out to be very hands-on, fighting as a seasonal fire fighter with DECs Wanneroo office, taking part in fire training courses and attending some of the biggest fires of the season.

He has also assisted with experimental burns with the DEC science divisions fire research team and has helped compile maps in preparation for the fire season.

I wanted to learn English and Australians were the friendliest English-speaking people I met in Europe, he said.

Plus Australia has the best weather and most different landscapes to Spain.

He has also been able to teach DEC staff about forest fire management in Spain.

He has much experience with the Spanish National Research Institute of Agriculture and Forestry.

DEC fire management services branch manager Rick Sneeuwjagt said WA and Spain had much in common with respect to the Mediterranean fire climate and vegetation fuels.

However, there are significant differences in the ownership of land as WA has large tracts of public lands, while Spains most vegetated areas are on private land, he said.

As a result, there are differences in the way fire is managed.

urn:contentItem:7WXC-N380-YBDY-R00B-00000-00crime stoppers2009-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisPg. 6crime stoppers

Toorbul fire

FIRE crews contained a forest fire at Toorbul on Thursday. The fire - in Pumicestone Rd, Toorbul - started about 7.20am. Four fire crews attended. About six hectares of land was burned out. Heavy machinery had to be used to construct fire breaks and backburning was performed in the western and southern sectors of the affected area. One helicopter conducted aerial observation and water bombing. No homes were threatened.

Truck blaze

A truck caught fire on the Bruce Highway at Narangba on Friday night, causing traffic congestion. The blaze in the southbound lanes of the highway left only one lane open for several hours. There were no reports of injuries.

Women struck

TWO women were taken to hospital on Friday night after they were hit by a vehicle on Kendall Rd, Bellmere. Police said that it was believed the Bellmere women, aged 18 and 17, were walking with three other people about 8pm when a vehicle crashed into them. The 18-year-old, who reportedly hit the bonnet and windscreen of the vehicle, was treated at Caboolture Hospital for spinal injuries. The second woman, who was allegedly struck and thrown on to a footpath, received treatment for cuts and abrasions. Another 17-year-old Bellmere woman has been assisting police with inquiries.

Home burns

INVESTIGATIONS are continuing into a destructive house fire at Deception Bay on Sunday night. Four fire crews responded to a call to the house fire on the corner of Isis St and Claverton Drive, Deception Bay, just after 7pm. The house suffered significant damage. Crews remained on scene, damping down until midnight. According to authorities, no one was injured in the blaze.

urn:contentItem:545T-HSJ1-JD67-101G-00000-00Plan set if earthquake strikes city2011-10-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Plan set if earthquake strikes cityBRAD WORRALL

THE earth trembles and roars, the seismic activity cracking the Hume Dam wall and unleashing millions of megalitres of water on Albury-Wodonga. The results are catastrophic - numerous fatalities, large numbers of injuries with many requiring hospitalisation. Properties are flooded, some of the Border cities' 82,000 people evacuated and many more further along the river.

An unprecedented national disaster rushes down the Murray River creating chaos, wreaking havoc on riverside communities. But in Wodonga there are just 410 beds available in community halls for the displaced. The motels are another option but they have a total capacity of about 700. Council civic services manager Mark Verbaken says an earthquake is unlikely but one that had to be planned for as part of the city's 180-page emergency management plan. He says grass fires and flash flooding are more likely. "But this plan is about looking at the potential for emergencies and setting in place plans and contacts that would provide our best response," Mr Verbaken said. "The report covers everything from windstorms to pandemics, terrorist attacks to aircraft crashes. "But the reality and history suggest that fire, floods and spring-summer storms are our most likely emergency. "With fires it is more likely to be grass fire, than a forest fire, and flash flooding rather than river flooding. "The fact is very few of these emergencies would stretch the demand to be able to lay people down overnight." On Monday night councillors voted unanimously in favour of adopting the plan that was also prompted by the recent history of emergencies in the city. The report to council said there was always the potential for a major accident on the Hume Freeway but most past emergencies were "primarily related to flooding". It highlighted flooding in 1996, 1998 and last year as well as fires in 1952 and 2003. The report also said pockets of Wodonga can be affected by "mini- cyclones". Cr Anna Speedie congratulated the work and detail that had gone into the plan.

urn:contentItem:4P0N-D910-TX53-72FD-00000-00Around the world in 80 seconds2007-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 11Around the world in 80 seconds

Helicopter deaths

ULAN BATOR, Mongolia: Fourteen people were killed and eight survived when a helicopter crashed into a mountain in north-central Mongolia while on a firefighting mission, a government official said yesterday.

The crash site was found on Saturday after the Russian-made Mi-8 helicopter was missing for several days.

Rescuers were still trying to retrieve survivors, officials said yesterday. said.

Authorities lost contact with the helicopter on Wednesday when it was bringing firefighters and equipment to a forest fire in Selenge province.

Darfur deployment

KHARTOUM: A UN security council delegation said it had secured the unconditional agreement of the Sudanese government for the deployment of a beefed-up peacekeeping force to Darfur.

After talks with President Omar al-Beshir, who had long held out against the proposed hybrid UN-African Union force of up to 23,000 peacekeepers, South African ambassador to the UN Dumisani Kumalo said he had raised no objections to its deployment.

World's oldest man

TOKYO: Tomoji Tanabe, a 111-year-old man from Japan, has been presented with a certificate for being the world's oldest male from Britain's Guinness World Records.

The document was delivered in person by Miyakonojo mayor Makoto Nagamine to Mr Tanabe's home yesterday, where he lives with his fifth-oldest son.

Mr Tanabe was born September 18, 1895, and has raised eight children.

urn:contentItem:59RN-F721-JCM0-60BF-00000-00NSW fires: easing conditions help crews bring Alpine, Lower Portland blazes under control2013-11-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNSW fires: easing conditions help crews bring Alpine, Lower Portland blazes under control

Easing weather conditions have helped fire crews gain the upper hand over two bushfires still burning in New South Wales.

A bushfire near Alpine in the Southern Highlands and another near Lower Portland on the Hawkesbury River are both now listed as "advice", meaning they do not presently pose a threat to homes.

The Southern Highlands fire caused the Old Hume Highway and the railway line to be closed over night, but those thoroughfares have now been reopened.

However, trains are travelling slowly through the area and motorists are being warned of smoke in the area.

Rural Fire Services Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons says crews are facing difficult conditions in the area.

"It's pretty rugged terrain, difficult to access, heavily forested country," he said.

"As we're seeing already today, a lot of those trees are damaged and they then become susceptible to collapse and fall along the fire ground, which is what we have got to be careful about when it comes to reopening roads and railway lines."

Commissioner Fitzsimmons says the fire near Hawkesbury is still being controlled.

"It was downgraded to advice around three or four o'clock this morning. There was more than 100 firefighters working on that last night," he said.

"It is going to require a deal of attention throughout today, but fortunately, like the other fire ground, conditions have eased considerably.

"Firefighters on the ground and the use of aircraft will seek to bring that fire under control throughout today.

"It's not declared contained yet, but it's not posing any threat to homes."

Commissioner Fitzsimmons says the next cycle of hot weather is expected to move through the state on Thursday, but until meaningful rainfall arrives the containment of the fire grounds will be tenuous for days, if not weeks.

Two fires still burning in state's south

Meanwhile, about 90 firefighters are working to contain two separate fires in remote forest escarpment in the state's south.

Both were ignited by lightning more than two weeks ago.

About 60 firefighters are trying to contain a forest fire burning through more than 7,000 hectares of Budawang National Park and private farmland around 25 kilometres north-east of Braidwood.

Specialist remote area fire crews are being winched into the region and water bombing is continuing today.

Without rain, the Shoalhaven Rural Fire Service says the fire is expected to continue burning for several weeks.

Further south, the Eurobodalla Rural Fire Service says 27 remote area fire fighters are trying to contain a 150-hectare blaze in the extremely steep and remote forests of Monga National Park, between the Kings Highway and Nelligen.

The fire has burnt out the historic Corn walking trail.

urn:contentItem:5VJH-FGR1-JBJ7-N14K-00000-00Victorian bushfires: Fears more homes will be lost as intense fires rage across state's east2019-03-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisVictorian bushfires: Fears more homes will be lost as intense fires rage across state's eastMelissa Cunningham, Joe Hinchliffe and Matilda Boseley

Homes and lives are under threat as nineteen intense bushfires rage across the state's east, including three major threatening fires which are burning out-of-control.

Homes and lives are under threat as nineteen intense bushfires rage across the state's east, including three major threatening fires which are burning out-of-control.

Nine properties have so far been destroyed including seven in the Bunyip State Park blaze, and another two by the Yinnar bushfire, a State Control Centre spokeswoman said.

Authorities are expecting to uncover more losses on Monday.

A wind change that swept eastward across Victoria after 9pm on Sunday eased firefighting efforts in areas south-east of Melbourne, with the Bunyip State Park downgraded slightly to a ???Watch and Act' warning level early Monday morning.

While the Bunyip blaze is currently within containment lines, Victorian emergency authorities are still urging residents to consider leaving their homes if they haven't already or if they are away from their properties not to return.

Among those devastated was Andrew Clarke, owner of Jinks Creek Winery. He said his family had lost everything after fire burnt through their winery at Tonimbuk.

He said he was sitting in a cafe in Bunyip after evacuating the night before when he learnt the bushfire had engulfed his rural property.

"We've lost everything," he said. "We've lost our whole livelihood."

Emergency warnings remain in place for multiple suburbs including Budgeree, Budgeree East, Jeeralang, Jeeralang Junction, Jeeralang North, Jumbuk, Yinnar and Yinnar South.

"Obviously there are some [fires] which are still a very high priority for us," Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp 3AW radio.

"Yinnar still has an emergency warning and the fire Bunyip now has a 'Watch and Act' warning but that's not to say we don't have significant work to do ... but we're in a lot better position than we were yesterday."

More than 500 people visited five emergency relief centres set up across the state's east on Sunday.

About 50 people spent a second night on blow-up mattresses on the basketball courts or sleeping inside their cars at Bellbird Park in Drouin, radio station 3AW reports.

Mr Crisp said authorities faced testing conditions on Monday, but cooler temperatures would assist firefighters.

"Milder temperatures and milder conditions will help us on some of our more significant fires," he said.

"But we'll still have a very challenging day ahead of us."

Yinnar South resident Bernard Marsh had gone to Melbourne for a reptile expo on Sunday when he received a phone call that the fires were burning near his home.

"I'm pretty confident if I haven't lost my house it's severely damaged ... it's entirely enveloped in the fire air," he told ABC on Monday.

"I've got two pairs of shorts and T-shirts to my name if [the house] is gone."

Mr Marsh said he lives at the end of a dirt road in the last house on the block.

"It's beautiful ... but it hasn't had a fire since the 30s so it's full of debris," he said. "When you live in this country ... the price of beauty is a bit of danger."

Firefighters and residents were also bracing for more homes to be lost.

At least three homes were destroyed by the 10,000 hectare Bunyip fire on Sunday, including one at Tonimbuk that exploded as it was engulfed in flames.

At least another two buildings were destroyed by another bushfire near Yinnar South in the Latrobe Valley, as more than a dozen fires raged across the state as temperatures reached their hottest during the day.

Hundreds of firefighters are battling to contain the blazes, as residents bunker down in evacuation centres, not knowing if their homes will be among those lost.

The Bunyip fire razed homes and sheds, and incinerated vineyards on Sunday, as thousands of people evacuated their homes.

While many residents chose to stay and defend their homes, others were forced to do so after being told it was too late to leave, with the Princes Freeway closed in both directions between Nar Nar Goon and Drouin.

The freeway, and many other local roads, could remain closed for days yet.

By Monday morning about 900 homes were left without power, with about 550 homes cut off about 2.40pm Sunday at Gembrook, Maryknoll, Nar Nar Goon and Tynong.

The severity of the blaze prompted Premier Daniel Andrews to implore people not to risk their lives - and put others in danger.

"Don't put yourself in harm's way and potentially add to the already considerable workload our firefighters have," he said.

Late Sunday afternoon firefighters began focusing on their own safety, on high alert for a wind change that was expected to make conditions even more unpredictable and dangerous.

More than 850 of them fought to control the blaze sparked by lightning strikes on Friday night, using 100 fire trucks, 18 heavy machines and 10 aircraft.

The change hit the Bunyip fire about 8pm bringing strong winds, cooler temperatures and pushing the fire away from several towns and towards the Bunyip State Park.

It petered out before reaching the fires further east.

More than 150 firefighters battled the Yinnar South fire.

Meanwhile, campers and daytrippers had to be evacuated from Wilsons Promontory, due a fire north of Tidal River.

At 5.30pm on Sunday, authorities issued an emergency warning for another large fire at Dargo, while a fourth major blaze also raged near Licola.

Despite the wind switching from the north-westerly to south-easterly direction, bringing cooler conditions, firefighters may have to wait until Wednesday before conditions change in their favour.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Chris Eagle said the Bunyip fire in Gippsland had "significantly expanded" on Sunday afternoon.

Mr Eagle said he expected to find more homes lost once the ash and smoke had cleared.

"We had three [destroyed properties] confirmed this morning, but given the fire's grown over 4000 hectares today, more will be impacted," he said.

At least 25 schools and 19 early childhood services will be closed in towns in south-eastern Victoria on Monday with roads cut and travel dangerous.

Federation University's Gippsland campus and Drouin Secondary College were among those to announce their closure on social media on Sunday with centres in Bunyip, Garfield and Jindivick also affected.

A full list of the closures can be seen on the emergency closures page of the Department of Education's website.

Firefighters were expecting similar conditions for the next few days and Mr Eagle said it might not be until Wednesday that a cold front bought "limited rain".

It was lightning strikes that ignited the Bunyip blaze on Friday night and four separate fires morphed into one on Saturday.

On Sunday, the fire burnt dangerously close to two electricity transmission lines linking the Latrobe Valley and Melbourne.

"Firefighters are protecting these transmission lines, both on the ground and through water bombing from the air," a company statement on Sunday afternoon said.

The lines are running at the north of the fire and at the southern border, near the Princes Freeway.

The company operates Victoria's electricity transmission network and said supply could be exposed to risk.

"However the situation is unpredictable, and may change quickly," the statement said.

Fire had already damaged power lines and poles in the Gippsland area with outages reported in Tonimbuk, Yinnar South and Budgeree.

Residents of Labertouche were door knocked and told to evacuate on Sunday afternoon.

Others in areas including Bunyip, Cornucopia, Garfield, Gentle Annie, Longwarry, Maryknoll, Nar Nar Goon, Tonimbuk and Tynong were told it was too late to leave and to take shelter immediately.

Two homes were also lost in the Budgeree-Wilsons Promontory fires, incident controller for those blazes, Peter West, told the ABC.

Several aircraft were sent from NSW to help fight the fires and emergency services are coordinating more support from across the country.

- with Liam Mannix, AAP

urn:contentItem:5HGX-KK51-F03R-N1RH-00000-00World's rarest ape is 'singing' on a Chinese island2015-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisWorld's rarest ape is 'singing' on a Chinese islandDarwin Malicdem

Nov 30, 2015( International Business Times Australia: http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Scientists have found the rarest ape in the world singing on an island in China. The species, called Hainan gibbon, are also considered one of the 25 most endangered primates in the world as people tend to boil their bodies to produce paste.<nl/>

As the dawn breaks on Futou Ling, a mountain on Hainan Island off China's south coast, the last remaining gibbons begin to sing. These species are not just considered as the world's rarest ape but also the world's rarest primate and potentially rarest mammal.<nl/> Scientists have found Hainan gibbons creating an intense musical cacophony, filling the tropical forest, every morning. Males climb to the treetops and start warbling, hooting and shrieking, and females and youngsters start to sing.<nl/> About 28 gibbons were found to survive in Bawangling National Nature Reserve in western Hainan. Researchers did not find the animals in any other areas.<nl/> The tiny population of Hainan gibbons are at high risk of typhoon, forest fire and outbreak of infectious diseases, which could wipe their entire species. However, researchers are working in an to prevent the gibbons to be the first primate to become extinct due to human activities.<nl/> 'The Hainan gibbon is the world's rarest ape, the world's rarest primate and, almost certainly, the world's rarest mammal,' said Samuel Turvey, a senior research fellow at the Zoological Society of London.<nl/> Hainan gibbons were considered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature as one of the world's 25 most endangered primates. A report[1], released on Nov.sc 24, shows that gibbons have the lowest recorded number of any species.<nl/> In a report by the National Geographic[2], Hainan gibbons have been devastated by poaching and deforestation. People use their bodies to make a gluey paste for Chinese medicine.<nl/> Hainan was originally home to thousands of gibbons however its forest was selectively logged for valuable timber and to make way for state-owned rubber plantations since 1960s. These devastating events led researchers to aim to fully understand how gibbons live and their needs to create a plan to save them.<nl/> Jessica Bryant, one of the researchers, has spent several seasons tracking gibbons. Bryant and her colleagues have found that gibbons tend to perform a song every day during dawn, and used their voice to track the animals.<nl/> She describes Hainan gibbons' song as 'the most beautiful of all.' But the team only have a small period of time to locate the gibbons before they fall silent.<nl/> 'If we don't find them in time, we have to wait another one or two hours until they sing again,' Bryant said. 'If we can find out how many there are, and where they live, we can focus on protecting and reforesting those areas.'<nl/> The scientists are aiming to identify the Hainan gibbons' declining population to provide plans to protect their number. The scientists are planning to build canopy bridges for gibbons, which are clumsy on the ground, to move through the fragmented forest.<nl/> They are also working for an emergency response plan to keep the gibbons from being wiped out by storms or other calamities.<nl/> Contact the writer at feedback@Ibtimes.com.au or tell us what you think below;;<nl/> [ 1]: http://iucn.org/about/work/programmes/species/?22190/Worlds-25-most-endangered-primates-revealed [ 2]:   http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/11/151129-hainan-gibbon-endangered-ape-animals-deforestation-conservation/

urn:contentItem:7W9R-8SM1-2PW5-F0N2-00000-00Vic: Eight Victorian firefighters join Canada-bound team2009-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Eight Victorian firefighters join Canada-bound teamMELBOURNE Aug 5

  Eight Victorian firefighters are travelling to Canada to return the favour to local fire crews who helped out in the aftermath of Black Saturday.
   The firefighters are among a team of 30 personnel from Australia and New Zealand flying out on Wednesday to battle forest fires burning in British Columbia.


   Twenty-two of the firefighters are Australian and eight are from New Zealand.
   They will be deployed in Canada for six weeks near the Whistler Blackcomb ski resort.
   Victorian Environment Minister Gavin Jennings said Canadian authorities issued a call for help after more than 500 blazes were sparked across British Columbia.
   "During February's Black Saturday bushfires Victoria received significant support from overseas firefighters, particularly from the United States, Canada and New Zealand," he said.
   The firefighters will be working on targeted operations, including as incident controllers, operations chiefs, fireline supervisors and fire behaviour analysts.
   "The firefighters will be able to enhance their already outstanding organisational skills and build rapport with the Canadian crews as well as expanding their knowledge of forest firefighting techniques, which they will be able to bring back and apply at home," Mr Jennings said.
   "The Canadian wildfires are burning in tall forest in steep and remote locations and we will only be sending fireline staff that have extensive experience with these conditions and can manage fires in such difficult situations."
   Fire chief Ewan Waller, who is also the chair of the Forest Fire Management Group, which is coordinating the deployment, said the exercise would not compromise preparations for Victoria's bushfire season.
   "It is essential that any deployment be done safely and with the firefighters back in time to continue with preparations and be well-rested for our summer," he said.

urn:contentItem:5MC8-1FF1-F031-X4BW-00000-00Australia's aquaculture industry confident white spot prawn disease has not spread to wild stock2016-12-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisAustralia's aquaculture industry confident white spot prawn disease has not spread to wild stockMarty McCarthy and Charlie McKillop

Authorities do not know how a devastating prawn disease got to aquaculture farms in Queensland, the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC) says.

However the corporation said white spot disease has not yet been detected in any wild prawn populations in Australia.

"There is no clear idea of where it came from," the FRDC's Peter Horvat said.

"[At this point in time] investigating the vector or pathogen's pathway into Australia isn't the priority, the clear focus is to contain and eradicate the white spot virus."

Biosecurity Queensland is continuing to destock and decontaminate ponds at two aquaculture farms south of Brisbane, and neighbouring farms are being checked to ensure it has not spread.

The disease does not pose any health risks to humans, but can cause major crop losses for prawn farmers.

Contain and destroy

White spot disease is widespread in Asia and in the Americas, but this is the first time it has been detected on prawn farms in Australia.

Establishing the pathway of a biosecurity incursion can help to identify if there are any other infected properties or areas.

However Mr Horvat said authorities needed to first make sure the disease was contained and destroyed.

"The who, the why and the how when you're dealing with a forest fire for example is not the primary concern," he said.

"You have got to deal with the crisis that is with them right this second, so they need to contain it and stop it from going any further."

The affected prawn farms are on the Logan River, south of Brisbane, but the FRDC said the disease has not yet been detected in nearby wild prawns.

"There is a testing program being run through Biosecurity Queensland and industry to test not only prawn farms in the area, but also undertaking surveys up and down the Logan River," Mr Horvat said.

"They are being tested regularly and to date there is no evidence that the disease has left the farm.

"The goal is to make sure we never let that happen."

Producers urged to be alert of biosecurity risks

Dallas Donovan is the operations manager for Seafarms Group, the largest prawn farming operation in Australia with about 160 hectares of productive ponds in north Queensland.

Mr Donovan said he was confident white spot disease could be eradicated, and the incursion would not be a blight on the country's highly regarded aquaculture industry.

"We have seen that in other countries where eradication has occurred and it requires a sustained effort and a good solid response," he said.

"This is something caused by the virus coming into the country in some form of crustacean, and we will let the epidemiologist determine how.

"But Australia's prawn farming industry remains highly sustainable and still clean and green."

Mr Donovan said it was important that farmers be alert to all biosecurity risks, and that the affected prawn farmers acted responsibly in reporting the disease to authorities.

"I think there would be some worrying times and tears for the owners of those properties but hats off to them," he said.

"They have communicated well with government and industry to get to the bottom of it, and have been more than cooperative to get the issue under control."

'Heart-wrenching' for prawn farmers

Many media reports have drawn links between WSD and the negligible impact on the supply of Christmas prawns.

However Mr Horvat from the FRDC said it was also important to acknowledge the wellbeing of the farmers affected.

"They are not large producers, like most primary producers around Australia they are small family-run business," he said.

"Having worked for the entire year in the lead up to Christmas and then having your stock destroyed is heart-wrenching from anyone's perspective.

"It is a very tough situation for the farmers, and industry are focussing on providing them with as much assistance and help as they can."

Identifying the symptoms

Although the disease is called white spot disease, authorities said there were other symptoms farmers should look for.

Prawns with WSD may have a loose shell with a pink to red discolouration, and may gather near the surface of the water.

Infected prawns may also stop eating, become lethargic or swim differently.

Aquaculture businesses who notice these symptoms are urged to contact authorities.

urn:contentItem:53R7-T4P1-JD3N-53HC-00000-00DSE's burning desire2011-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11DSE's burning desirePETER HUNT

FOREST FUEL

THE Victorian Government plans to burn 225,000ha of the state's forest this season in its bid to reach an annual rolling target of 390,000ha by 2014.

It is a huge task, given the Department of Sustainability and Environment fell just short of its 2010-11 target of 200,000ha, burning out 188,000ha last season.

But Minister for Bushfire Response Peter Ryan is confident DSE can deliver on the Government's commitment, which was one of the 2009 Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission's key recommendations.

``The Victorian Coalition Government is committed to implementing a long-term program of prescribed burning based on an annual rolling target of 5 per cent of public land as recommended by the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission,'' Mr Ryan said.

``In 2010-11 more than 188,000ha of planned burning was completed.

``This represents 94 per cent of the planned program for that year and is the largest program completed in more than 20 years.

``Any annual shortfall will be made up in subsequent years.''

The Government has also promised to divert any remnant funding from shortfalls in the burn target into subsequent years. Yet it remains unclear whether last season's shortfall will be rolled into the 2011-12 target.

DSE is in the process of finalising its future Fire Operations Plans, but at this stage has set this season's target at 225,000ha, another 290,000ha in 2012-13 and 390,000ha in 2013-14.

The Royal Commission also recommended DSE report annually on prescribed burning outcomes ``in a manner that meets public accountability objectives, including publishing details of targets, area burnt, funds expended on the program, and impacts on biodiversity''.

DSE is yet to publish information on funds expended on last season's fuel-reduction burns.

The Forest Fire Victoria lobby group has called on the government and DSE to deliver on its promise for greater transparency on reaching burn targets.

``Part of our concern is that the (DSE) website doesn't allow the great unwashed like me to take a close look at how they're performing,'' FFV president Athol Hodgson said.

urn:contentItem:803B-NNN1-2RG7-23WD-00000-00Burn critics risking lives: Forestry Tasmania2010-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisBurn critics risking lives: Forestry Tasmania

Forestry Tasmania says environment groups could put lives at risk by criticising fuel reduction burns.

Conservationists at the Huon Valley Environment Centre say residents in Geeveston in southern Tasmania were given only a couple of hours' notice of a 300 hectare button grass burn-off at Four Foot Plains on Tuesday.

The group says that was insufficient, and people should have been told about the burn-off plans well in advance.

Forestry Tasmania fire manager Tony Blanks says the burn-off will save lives.

"This was a typical fuel reduction burn that we do as part of our community protection," Mr Banks said.

"The Four Foot Plains is the closest button grass plain on the north-west of Geeveston, and in the event of a forest fire it's likely to finish up pitching sparks into the township, so it was being done for community protection."

Mr Blanks says smoke levels from Tuesday's burn were lower than average winter levels.

He says fuel reduction burns are a matter of timing.

"We have to seize the opportunities when they occur in terms of the weather.

"If we'd given more notice of this then probably we wouldn't have been able to do the burn because we expect rain tonight, and in fact that rain is what we want to help bring the smoke out of the air and settle the fire down. It helps to make the fire safer than it already is."

Forestry Tasmania says it has not received any complaints from the Geeveston community, and the smoke from the burn-offs has now cleared.

'Call for change'

The Huon Valley Environment Centre says it recognises fuel reduction burns are needed to keep communities safe, but says the issue is what it has labelled Forestry Tasmania's mismanagement of the practice.

The Centre's Jenny Weber says the Parks and Wildlife Service and the Tasmania Fire Service would be better suited to managing fuel reduction burns.

urn:contentItem:4P0W-XGX0-TXN5-T2Y5-00000-00Excessive speed in fatal crash2006-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Excessive speed in fatal crashJOANNE McCARTHY

THE girlfriend of a man injured seriously in a motorbike crash on a state forest fire trail on Sunday worked frantically to keep his friend alive after a bike outing went tragically wrong.

The woman carried out CPR on Dale Lightfoot, 22, of East Gosford, on the Central Coast, after his bike was involved in a fatal head-on collision with another bike on the Wallaby Road fire trail in Ourimbah State Forest.

Mr Lightfoot and the rider of the second bike, a 30-year-old Sydney man, were with a group of riders who set off along the fire trail about 4pm.

It is believed Mr Lightfoot was heading north on the trail when his bike and the other one collided.

A preliminary police report to the coroner said excessive speed was a factor in the crash.

Tuggerah Lakes police confirmed an unregistered Kawasaki 125cc motorcycle and an unregistered 250cc Yamaha motorbike were taken from the scene.

Mr Lightfoot was pronounced dead at Wyong Hospital.

His parents were advised of their son's death while on holiday overseas.

They returned home yesterday to identify his body.

The injured man was flown by the Westpac rescue helicopter to Newcastle's John Hunter Hospital, where he was reported to be in a serious but stable condition yesterday.

urn:contentItem:4THH-CCN0-TX5N-00HC-00000-00Childs returns2008-09-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisSCENEPg. 84Childs returns

UNSTOPPABLE American singer-songwriter Toni Childs is back with an emotionally hard hitting new album titled Keep The Faith.

Childs will unleash her new songs, a blend of roots, rock and folk gospel songs, at Twin Towns on Saturday night.

Best known for her heavily R&B-influenced track Don't Walk Away, Childs hit the big time in 1988 when her debut album Union went double platinum in Australia.

Twenty years later, Keep The Faith is her fourth studio album.

It contains the powerful Because You're Beautiful which earned her a 2004 Emmy Award for best music and lyrics, and fresh pop ballad, One Life.

Childs, who ran away from home when she was 15 to pursue a career as a singer-songwriter after seeing Pink Floyd in concert, has a talent for picking the mood of the times.

Her new projects demonstrate her enormous soul and vision.

``The best part of re-emerging from the darkness and learning to embrace music once again, is simply the opportunity to evolve and get down to the core of my purpose,'' she said.

``It's been a really wonderful journey.

``I feel like I'm a phoenix rising.

``I burned down to an ash and then came through that forest fire healthier and stronger than ever before.

``This album is a real departure from my other work in that it is a much more basic and rootsy collection of music.''

l Toni Childs plays Twin Towns at 8.30pm on Saturday. Tickets are $45. For bookings or more information call 5536 2277, or visit www.twintowns. com.au.

urn:contentItem:4R45-DM10-TXX1-V0J4-00000-00Long summer looms2007-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisPg. 5Long summer looms

FIREFIGHTERS are bracing themselves for a long, hot summer with recent rains contributing to tinderbox conditions .

City of Wanneroo chief bushfire control officer Mike Teraci said local residents could help firefighters by being extra vigilant this summer.

Basically all the rain we have had lately means that more grass has been growing, he said.

Once that grass dries out there will be more fuel for the fires to spread and they will become more intense.

He recommended that before summer started homeowners prepare a bush fire plan.

They should also regularly clean their gutters, get rid of excess rubbish, grass and bush from their property and avoid burn offs in windy conditions.

Mr Teraci said people should not be afraid to contact a ranger or the fire brigade for advice, even if they thought they were out of bush fire range.

North of the township of Wanneroo can be a bad area for fires in summer, but basically any bushland area can be affected, he said. Residents should have a plan they can enact in the case of a fire, whether that means evacuation or another action.

Mr Teraci said forest fire managers were now better equipped to handle bushfires after the release of the findings of a multi-million dollar research program.

Project Vesta is one of Australia s largest and most comprehensive research projects into the behaviour and spread of high-intensity eucalypt forest fires.

urn:contentItem:57FJ-VPF1-F0J6-J2DF-00000-00DARTMOOR district residents were on edge last night2013-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1DARTMOOR district residents were on edge last night

DARTMOOR district residents were on edge last night as a huge forest fire continued uncontrolled through pine plantations and the Lower Glenelg National Park.

Late yesterday, a south-westerly wind change pushed the front towards Drik Drik less than 10 kilometres from Dartmoor.

Embers were drifting over homes and sheds in the farming hamlet late yesterday as authorities scaled up their emergency response with fire crews rallying to protect up to 10 homes under threat.

Nearby Mumbannar residents were on emergency alert.

Police were despatched to check on the safety of isolated and vulnerable residents.

About 300 firefighters are battling to control the blaze on several fronts which is expected to burn for several days.

urn:contentItem:7VH0-HJX1-2RYX-1090-00000-00Inferno created atomic fireballs, inquiry told2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Inferno created atomic fireballs, inquiry toldNORRIE ROSS, MELBOURNE

BLACK Saturday's 173 victims were defenceless in the face of a firestorm that created fireballs of atomic force, a Royal Commission heard yesterday.

The commission heard that Victoria's fire warning system broke down and people remained in their homes, unaware of the inferno.

Counsel assisting the commission, Jack Rush QC, said the ``stay or go early'' warning system might have misled people who did not understand the magnitude of what they were facing.

Mr Rush said the effectiveness of the 000 emergency system, radio and internet warnings would also come under close scrutiny. ``There will be evidence to suggest that accurate and timely information was not available during 7 February, 2009,'' Mr Rush said.

``Persons who chose to stay and defend their properties did so entirely unaware of the severity, the extremity, the intensity of the fires they would face.''

Mr Rush said the maximum intensity that a forest fire can be controlled is expressed as 4000 kilowatts per metre. On Black Saturday, the intensity reached 100,000 kilowatts per metre. ``Not only the intensity of the fire, the heat of the fire, but its speed was phenomenal,'' Mr Rush said. ``Fire spotted kilometres ahead, fireballs seemingly of atomic force came before the fire.''

The opening day of the commission was dogged by more complaints that individual victims were being denied the right to give evidence in person.

Mat Tinkler, acting executive director a public interest law clearing house, said applications from 30 individuals and communities were rejected without their barristers getting the chance to put their case.

``Money is no object for the big players, who are briefing the country's top lawyers to appear,'' Mr Tinkler said.

urn:contentItem:7YJ1-KRS1-2RYX-146X-00000-00Doom & gloom2010-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Doom & gloom

TRUCK'S WRONG TURN KILLS 32

Thirty-two people were killed when a truck travelling in the wrong direction collided head-on with a bus in northeastern China.

A further 21 people were injured and taken to hospital after the accident, which happened on a section of an expressway undergoing maintenance in the city of Fuxin in Liaoning province.

Three people in the truck and 28 bus passengers died on the spot, with another person dying later in hospital.

14 DEAD AFTER PALACE ATTACK

Somalia's al-Qaida-inspired Shebab rebels attacked the presidential palace in Mogadishu yesterday, sparking a battle that left at least 14 civilians dead.

Government forces backed by African Union troops retaliated to fend off the insurgents, whose offensive against the presidential compound came as President Sharif Sheikh Ahmed was attending a conference in Turkey.

BATTLE TO SAVE PASSENGERS

At least 19 people were killed and another 71 injured when a train derailed in a mountainous area of east China yesterday after a landslide damaged the tracks.

Police warned the toll could rise with rescuers still trying to cut into the twisted wreckage of carriages after some of them overturned in the accident in Jiangxi province.

The train, heading from Shanghai for the tourist city of Guilin in southern China, derailed in the early hours of the morning.

SUSPECTED BOMB ATTACK FOILED

A suspected republican bomb-making factory has been raided by police in Northern Ireland, with two men arrested.

Among the items found in the raid at Dundalk, Co.Louth, were two large modified gas cylinders fixed on a trailer.

Police believe they thwarted an imminent attack. The men, one in his 30s and the other in his 50s, are being questioned.

FIGHTING FIRE PROVES FATAL

Twelve people died in a forest fire in southwestern China after they volunteered to fight the blaze.

The victims were among a group of villagers in Yunnan province who became trapped when fierce winds fanned the flames.

urn:contentItem:7V0M-HD01-2PW5-H1GW-00000-00WA: Experts conduct inquiry to parallel that of royal commision2009-02-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:45:39ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSWA: Experts conduct inquiry to parallel that of royal commisionPERTH Feb 12

  Australia's key bushfire research organisation is mustering experts for an investigation into the behaviour of Australia's deadliest blazes.
   The federally-funded Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre (BCRC), which brings together researchers from private industry, universities, the CSIRO and other public organisations, is preparing to coordinate an inquiry into all aspects of the bushfires.


   It will assist Victorian fire authorities, although it will be conducted separately from the royal commission into the fires, announced by the Victorian government.
   BCRC spokesman David Bruce said details of the investigation program, to be conducted by many of the nation's leading fire behaviour specialists, are being finalised and are expected to be revealed later on Thursday.
   Among the experts joining the investigation is Lachie McCaw, from the science division of the West Australian Department of Environment and Conservation.
   DEC Director-General Keiran McNamara said Dr McCaw had conducted investigations into a number of serious WA bushfires and had helped lead a recent multi-million dollar study of forest fire behaviour in dry eucalypt forests.
   Mr McNamara said the program, Project Vesta, had led to revised fire behaviour prediction tables now used by land management and fire agencies throughout Australia.
   "Project Vesta also was critical in identifying what is now called the 'dead man zone' - an unburnt area between fire crews and the flank of a fire that can flare instantly in the event of a windshift," he said.
   Mr McNamara said that while in Victoria, Dr McCaw would investigate the main factors that led to such extreme fire behaviour.
   "This information will make a major contribution to subsequent inquiries into the bushfires and their impacts," Mr McNamara said.
